linkTarget.anchoringText: The gas fields are located offshore Trinidad (Figure 1) and flow into hubs culminating onshore in a major gas processing facility.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Offshore Trinidad showing the gas field locations in the red shading - BPTT acreage is shown in dark yellow.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Offshore Trinidad showing the gas field locations in the red shading - BPTT acreage is shown in dark yellow.

linkTarget.anchoringText: They are defined as having producing wells that have ceased production and have sufficient dynamic and static information to do this analysis. This analysis is an integration of all the dynamic information available for each reservoir. [9]. The procedure is outlined in Figure 2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Flow Diagram showing how the drive mechanism is defined

formatted-caption.caption-text: Flow Diagram showing how the drive mechanism is defined

linkTarget.anchoringText: The effect of the aquifer volumes and connectivity can be divided into three broad categories [2]. This is demonstrated on the classical P/z plot below in Figure 3. The P/z plot is based on the material balance equation for gas reservoirs and assumes all examples have the same static gas in place. The pink line and point on the plot shows a case of pure volumetric depletion where the connected gas in place calculated, agrees with the x-axis extrapolation. The abandonment pressure and cessation of production is largely due to the platform back pressure. Low pressure access, such as compression in offshore facilities, can increase the recovery factor.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: P/z plot showing three aquifer strength types - volumetric (pink), weak water drive (light blue), strong water drive (dark blue)

formatted-caption.caption-text: P/z plot showing three aquifer strength types - volumetric (pink), weak water drive (light blue), strong water drive (dark blue)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Sub-faulting to these regional faults locally influence structures and creates the traps for many reservoirs. These faults also add complexity to the reservoir by causing baffles or barriers to fluid flow which has short and long term effects on production. Where faults formed part of the trapping mechanism and/or were part of the sub-regional extent of the reservoir, the reservoir was designated to have some structural limit to the aquifer. The degree of aquifer limits varies by the number and geometry of faults that create the trap. Five classes of structural limits to the aquifer were defined (See figure 4). This in addition to structural dip of reservoir was catalogued for each reservoir.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Cartoons showing how different structural trapping geometries affect the access of the aquifer. a) No structural elements to trap. Aquifer access from all sides of structure b) One side of structure bounded by a fault. Aquifer access from 3 sides of structure c) Two sides of the structure bounded by faults. Aquifer access limited to two opposite sides of structure d) Two faults merge at one end of structure. Aquifer access limited to 1 side of structure e) Trap and aquifer completely surrounded by faults. No connection to aquifer

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cartoons showing how different structural trapping geometries affect the access of the aquifer. a) No structural elements to trap. Aquifer access from all sides of structure b) One side of structure bounded by a fault. Aquifer access from 3 sides of structure c) Two sides of the structure bounded by faults. Aquifer access limited to two opposite sides of structure d) Two faults merge at one end of structure. Aquifer access limited to 1 side of structure e) Trap and aquifer completely surrounded by faults. No connection to aquifer

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: No structural elements to trap. Aquifer access from all sides of structure
One side of structure bounded by a fault. Aquifer access from 3 sides of structure
Two sides of the structure bounded by faults. Aquifer access limited to two opposite sides of structure
Two faults merge at one end of structure. Aquifer access limited to 1 side of structure
Trap and aquifer completely surrounded by faults. No connection to aquifer

linkTarget.anchoringText: The shelf edge deltas developed multiple coarsening upward parasequences modified by storm and wave processes and long-shore currents. These proximal delta-front successions pass gradually into ten to one hundred meters thick distal delta front mud-dominated upper slope deposits characterized by a wide variety of sedimentary processes, (fig. 5a, and ref [1]).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5a
image-wrap.caption: Cartoons showing the dominant facies association in the delta front setting.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cartoons showing the dominant facies association in the delta front setting.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In some areas there are additional depositional elements such as slumping, canyon and channel development, and soft sediment deformation, see Fig. 5b. In depositional settings these features can create stratigraphic edges to reservoirs and help define the reservoir trap. Within the reservoir, the scale of these elements in combination with varying degrees of connectivity between sand bodies creates vertical and horizontal barriers and baffles. This adds complexity to fluid flow and can affect production rate and recovery. In these instances the reservoir is designated to have stratigraphic limits to the aquifer.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5b
image-wrap.caption: Cartoons showing additional facies associated with reservoirs in the Columbus Basin.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cartoons showing additional facies associated with reservoirs in the Columbus Basin.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Aquifer connectivity. This is described as the area of the hydrocarbon/aquifer interface (acres) multiplied by the average permeability (mD) of the reservoir. This is an attempt to quantify the degree of connectivity between the aquifer and the reservoir (Figure 6a).

image-wrap.label: Figure 6a
image-wrap.caption: Cartoon showing bottom water reservoir architecture configuration – 100% Bottom Water

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cartoon showing bottom water reservoir architecture configuration – 100% Bottom Water

linkTarget.anchoringText: Well Position. A Qualitative estimate of position of well on structure relative to the Gas/ Water Contact edge (Crestal, Midway, Close to edge) with quantitative estimates of vertical and lateral standoff distances (feet) (Figure 6b).

image-wrap.label: Figure 6b
image-wrap.caption: Cartoon showing edge water reservoir architecture configuration – 100% Edge Water

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cartoon showing edge water reservoir architecture configuration – 100% Edge Water

linkTarget.anchoringText: Traditionally not much analysis has been documented in the literature on mature reservoirs to understand the impact of the geology of the aquifers on the resulting drive mechanism and recovery factor Analysis as seen in Figure 7 has been limited to the classification of edge versus bottom drive and the petrophysics. The database that was created for this study enabled the team to use Spotfire™ analysis to investigate trends and patterns between reservoirs with some of the results shown below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Traditional Analysis of impact of geology on aquifer pressure support

formatted-caption.caption-text: Traditional Analysis of impact of geology on aquifer pressure support

linkTarget.anchoringText: The first focus area was a quick look into the relationship between sediment age and pool size. In Figure 8 below, Pleistocene rocks (TQ) appear to have higher incidences of pressure support from the aquifer when compared to the older Pliocene (TP) rocks. This is likely due to the fact that most of the TQ reservoirs have higher porosity and permeability and as a result higher aquifer connectivity. Most are also shallower reservoirs where the faulting may typically be like Figure 4b and so the reservoir is connected to a large aquifer volume and as a result leads to a good combination of higher aquifer connectivity and volume.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Spotfire™ plot of simple criteria aquifer pressure support for gas fields in the Columbus Basin

formatted-caption.caption-text: Spotfire™ plot of simple criteria aquifer pressure support for gas fields in the Columbus Basin

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 9 combines a number of different geologic criteria: 1) Y-axis - aquifer connectivity (permeability x aquifer interface area) 2) X-axis - % of Hydrocarbon bearing sand at crest (edge water would be 100%) and then split according to structural limits in the aquifer (Increasing numerical value indicates an increase in structural limits) and 3) Shape - stratigraphic limits to the aquifer denoted by the shapes (cross indicates thin-bedded pay). Figure 10 is a similar type of plot.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Spotfire™ plot showing relationships between aquifer connectivity / structural limits / drive mechanism and percent of hydrocarbon bearing sand at crest of the structure

formatted-caption.caption-text: Spotfire™ plot showing relationships between aquifer connectivity / structural limits / drive mechanism and percent of hydrocarbon bearing sand at crest of the structure

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 9 combines a number of different geologic criteria: 1) Y-axis - aquifer connectivity (permeability x aquifer interface area) 2) X-axis - % of Hydrocarbon bearing sand at crest (edge water would be 100%) and then split according to structural limits in the aquifer (Increasing numerical value indicates an increase in structural limits) and 3) Shape - stratigraphic limits to the aquifer denoted by the shapes (cross indicates thin-bedded pay). Figure 10 is a similar type of plot.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Updated Analysis showing some correlation between drive mechanism and the geological elements

formatted-caption.caption-text: Updated Analysis showing some correlation between drive mechanism and the geological elements

linkTarget.anchoringText: Field 1, segment 2 was produced by 2 wells over 10 years. Well A was placed crestally, 5100 ft. from the aquifer edge while Well B was 1200 ft. away. Segment 1 was also produced by 2 wells, one on the edge and one on the crest as shown in Figure 1a.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Segment 3 in Field 1 was produced by 1 well over 8 years. Well A was placed crestally, 1393 ft from the aquifer edge as shown in figure 2a below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2a
image-wrap.caption: Map showing well and segment location and fault pattern for Field 1, Segment3

formatted-caption.caption-text: Map showing well and segment location and fault pattern for Field 1, Segment3

linkTarget.anchoringText: Stratigraphy – This sand is deposited on the active delta plain. Typically there is stratigraphic variability within this environment but a high degree of interconnectivity between sand bodies. Shales therefore are not laterally extensive and discontinuous, only forming baffles to flow. Log correlations show the sand package is consistent sub-regionally and there are no major stratigraphic boundaries in the reservoir that could create a barrier to flow. (Figure 2b.)

image-wrap.label: Figure 2b
image-wrap.caption: Well log sections showing rock properties for segment 3 between Field 1 and an adjacent field to the south

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well log sections showing rock properties for segment 3 between Field 1 and an adjacent field to the south

linkTarget.anchoringText: Segment 3 in Field 1 has pressure transient analysis overlays that show movement between 2007 and 2008 indicative of the aquifer. The producing well stopped producing due to liquid loading. In this strong water drive example; an active aquifer mechanism is confirmed via pressure derivative changes shown by the blue arrow between the green plot and the blue plot (fig 2c). The latest derivative in brown indicating two phase segregation indicated by the blue oval. The pressure history demonstrates the strong degree of depressurization post depletion.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2c
image-wrap.caption: Pressure Transient Analysis Derivative Overlays for Field 1 Segment 3

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pressure Transient Analysis Derivative Overlays for Field 1 Segment 3

image-wrap.label: Figure 2d
image-wrap.caption: P/z Analysis for Field 1 Segment 3

formatted-caption.caption-text: P/z Analysis for Field 1 Segment 3

linkTarget.anchoringText: Reservoir /aquifer bottom water configuration (33% of sand is gas bearing at crest of structure) and shallow structural dip of <5 degrees. This type of reservoir has a large aquifer/reservoir interface area coupled with the high permeabilities results in high aquifer connectivity (Figure 2e).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2e
image-wrap.caption: North to south cross sections for Field 1 Segment 3 showing the bottom water reservoir / aquifer configuration

formatted-caption.caption-text: North to south cross sections for Field 1 Segment 3 showing the bottom water reservoir / aquifer configuration
